title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness when hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not apply subsection (a) of Section 3111 of the Internal Revenue Code to wages paid to qualified individuals for services performed during a specific period. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes on wages paid to qualified individuals for services performed in their trade or business or in furtherance of activities related to their tax-exempt status. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" defines a qualified employer as any employer other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. A qualified individual is someone who begins employment with a qualified employer after February 3, 2010, and before January 1, 2011, and certifies by signed affidavit that they have not been. Qualified individuals must begin employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011. They must certify that they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting the job and cannot be replacing another employee unless that employee left voluntarily or for cause. Qualified individuals must start employment with a qualified employer between specific dates and certify they meet certain criteria. The employer can elect to not apply this subsection. A qualified employer may elect to not apply this subsection. The term 'wages' excludes amounts paid to a qualified individual by a qualified employer during the 1-year period from the hiring date. The subsection excludes wages paid to a qualified individual by a qualified employer during the 1-year period from the hiring date, unless the employer elects not to apply this provision. Amounts equal to the revenue reduction are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments made by this section appropriate amounts to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. These amendments apply to wages paid after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 multiplied by the number of retained workers who meet certain criteria during the taxable year. A retained worker is a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer during the taxable year. A retained worker, as defined in section 3111(d)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, is an individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling at least 80% of the wages in the first 26 weeks.
